Grouped_Utterances: I guess just the ongoing tension with my dad. It’s still bothering me.

I understand. Last time we talked about your feelings of being in "one note land." Have you noticed any changes in that? Not really. I still feel kind of flat. I try to shake it off, but it lingers. That sounds tough. Have you had any moments where you felt more engaged or excited about something? Well, I did go to that basketball game with my friend again, and it was fun. But it was just a temporary high. It’s great that you had a good time at the game! What do you think keeps you from feeling that excitement more often? I think it’s just life here. Sometimes it feels like a routine, and I’m not sure how to break out of it. Routines can definitely feel stifling. Have you thought about what you might want to change in your daily life to add some variety? I’ve considered trying new hobbies, but I often end up putting it off. I think I’m just too tired or unmotivated. That’s understandable. Perhaps we could explore some small, manageable changes you could try? What’s one hobby you’ve thought about? I’ve always wanted to try painting. I think it would be relaxing, but I just never get around to it. Fantastic! Let’s check in about that in our next session. Now, you mentioned feeling more reserved and secluded over the years. Can you share more about that? Yeah, I just find myself not wanting to go out as much. I used to be more social, but now it feels exhausting. It’s common for social energy to fluctuate. Do you think there’s anything specific that triggers that exhaustion for you? I think it’s just the pressure of having to interact with people. Sometimes I feel like I don’t know what to say or how to act. That pressure can be overwhelming. Have you ever tried any techniques to help manage those feelings before social situations? I’ve read about deep breathing exercises, but I haven’t really practiced them. Yeah, I think it would help. I just feel like we’re stuck in this cycle of arguing. It sounds frustrating. What do you think contributes to that cycle? I think it’s a mix of misunderstandings and him pushing me to do things I’m not comfortable with. I haven’t really figured that out yet. I’m not sure he would listen. He might get defensive, but maybe it would help him see my side.

Deep breathing can be a great tool. Would you like to try a simple breathing exercise together now? Sure, I’d like that. Let’s take a deep breath in for four counts… hold for four… and exhale for four. Repeat that a few times. How does that feel? It feels calming, actually. I think I should try this before I go out next time. It can be challenging, but expressing your feelings calmly might open the door for a better understanding. Would you like to role-play that conversation here? That could be useful. I’d like to see how I might phrase things. Great! Let’s start with how you might express your feelings about the situation without placing blame. Okay, I would say something like, “Dad, I feel overwhelmed when you tell me to reach out to her. It makes me feel pressured.”

Painting sounds like a wonderful creative outlet! Would you be willing to set aside some time this week to try it out? I could try to make time for it, maybe just an hour or so. That sounds like a great plan. Remember, it doesn’t have to be perfect; just enjoy the process. How do you feel about that idea? I feel good about it. It might help me clear my mind. That’s a great idea! Practicing it regularly can help you feel more centered. What other strategies do you think might help you in social situations? Maybe I could try to set smaller goals, like just talking to one new person instead of feeling like I have to mingle with everyone. Setting smaller goals is an excellent approach! It can make socializing feel less daunting. Would you like to set a specific goal for your next outing? Yes, I think I’ll aim to introduce myself to one new person at the next event I attend. It might be helpful to communicate your feelings more directly to him. Have you thought about how you might approach that conversation? It’s possible. Remember, you can’t control his reaction, but you can control how you express yourself. Would you feel ready to try that in real life? I think I could try it. It’s worth a shot. Absolutely! I’m proud of you for wanting to address this. Let’s touch base about how it goes in our next session.
